Parsing expressions

Source: vignettes/parsing-expressions.Rmd
parsing-expressions.Rmd

Some functions are quite easy to translate in Polars syntax, such as distinct() (which calls $unique() under the hood). Things are more challenging when we try to convert classic R expressions to Polars expressions to use them in mutate() or summarize(). This article walks you through the process of converting these expressions, so that you can understand the strengths and weaknesses of tidypolars.

Why should we use Polars expressions?

Polars provides a way to evaluate custom functions using $apply() or $map(). However, this is strongly discouraged and people should use Polars’ numerous built-in functions, that are optimized and parallelized (most of the time) internally.

Therefore, there seems to be a conflict between the two objectives of tidypolars:

  • provide Polars performance
  • keep using R and tidyverse syntax

How does tidypolars work with expressions?

We need to parse expressions that R users provide and convert them to Polars syntax. To do so, tidypolars works in several steps.

The main tools in this rewriting process are parse() and getParseData(). For example, suppose we have this string that contains an expression that a user wants to pass in pl_mutate():

expr <- "mean(Petal.Length) / sum(Sepal.Width)"

Using parse() and getParseData(), we can represent this as a table with each element:

parsed <- parse(text = expr, keep.source = TRUE)
p_d <- utils::getParseData(parsed)
p_d
#>    line1 col1 line2 col2 id parent                token terminal         text
#> 23     1    1     1   37 23      0                 expr    FALSE             
#> 10     1    1     1   18 10     23                 expr    FALSE             
#> 1      1    1     1    4  1      3 SYMBOL_FUNCTION_CALL     TRUE         mean
#> 3      1    1     1    4  3     10                 expr    FALSE             
#> 2      1    5     1    5  2     10                  '('     TRUE            (
#> 4      1    6     1   17  4      6               SYMBOL     TRUE Petal.Length
#> 6      1    6     1   17  6     10                 expr    FALSE             
#> 5      1   18     1   18  5     10                  ')'     TRUE            )
#> 11     1   20     1   20 11     23                  '/'     TRUE            /
#> 21     1   22     1   37 21     23                 expr    FALSE             
#> 12     1   22     1   24 12     14 SYMBOL_FUNCTION_CALL     TRUE          sum
#> 14     1   22     1   24 14     21                 expr    FALSE             
#> 13     1   25     1   25 13     21                  '('     TRUE            (
#> 15     1   26     1   36 15     17               SYMBOL     TRUE  Sepal.Width
#> 17     1   26     1   36 17     21                 expr    FALSE             
#> 16     1   37     1   37 16     21                  ')'     TRUE            )

In particular, we are interested in the columns token and text. To get variable names and replace them with pl$col(varname), we keep only token == SYMBOL and then we check which text values match the column names of our data.

We can also extract function calls with token == SYMBOL_FUNCTION_CALL. For each function call, we check whether there’s a Polars equivalent. If there is one, we prefix the function call with pl_. For example, mean(x) will be transformed as pl_mean(x), which is defined as a very short function that returns the Polars expression x$mean().

Finally, one last challenge is that R functions and their Polars equivalent do not necessarily have the same arguments. For example, mean() has an argument na.rm to drop missing values. In Polars, this is done automatically. Overall, when some elements of the R function are not used by Polars, it will generate a message of the form:

When the dataset is a Polars DataFrame or LazyFrame, `mean()` only needs 
one argument. Additional arguments will not be used.

Now, you know how tidypolars converts R expressions into Polars expressions.

Drawback

A drawback of this approach is that tidypolars can only work with the functions it was programmed to know. For example, it recognizes ifelse() but if this ifelse() is buried in a custom function that you defined elsewhere, it is not possible to convert it to Polars syntax so you will lose the performance gains here.
